import random
import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.image as mpimg
%matplotlib inline
source.2f04c829:
SAMPLE_SIZE=5
sample = [(k, 0) for k in random.sample(df[df['Pawpularity'] <= 10]['Id'].values.tolist(), SAMPLE_SIZE)]
sample.extend([(k, 1) for k in random.sample(df[df['Pawpularity'] > 90]['Id'].values.tolist(), SAMPLE_SIZE)])
random.shuffle(sample)
source.3205dcd2:
total = 0
for id, score in sample:
    img = mpimg.imread(f'/kaggle/input/petfinder-pawpularity-score/train/{id}.jpg')
    plt.imshow(img)
    plt.show()
    value = int(input('Type 0 for low score and 1 for high score: '))
    if value == score:
        total += 1
        print("correct!")
    else:
        print("wrong!")
print(f"Final score: {total}/{2*SAMPLE_SIZE}")
source.277aa2d1:
This notebook is actually a game.

You will be presented with 10 images, 5 with scores <= 10, and 5 with scores >= 90.

For each image you will have to guess whether the score is high (1) or low (0).

After playing the game, please, post your score and thoughts in the comments.

I created this notebook out of doubt.

After playing it multiple times and getting scores in the range from 2/10 to 6/10 ON MOST EXTREME CASES I feel like it makes no sense to invest time and energy (both mine and electrical energy) on this. I asked my wife to play and she scored 3/10.

Don't get me wrong, I love the idea of the competition, and I think that it would be super cool if we could contribute to improving the rate of animal adoption.

But can we really do it in this case?
